elements.content: The synthesis, characterization, and photophysical properties of two novel ligands, 5LINMe-1,2-HOPO (1) and H(2,2)-1,2-HOPO (2), which utilize the 1,2-HOPO chelate as a sensitizer for Eu(III) are reported. In addition, the former ligand was structurally characterized as the Eu(III) complex by X-ray crystallography. The [Eu(1)2]- complex of the tetradentate ligand (1) is stable in aqueous solution, to a limiting concentration of ca. 7 × 10-9 M, and retains the superior photophysical performance noted for the 1,2-HOPO sensitizer. By contrast, the octadentate ligand (2) has vastly improved stability as the [Eu(2)]- complex upon further dilution, to a limiting concentration of ca. 5 × 10-17 M, which is beyond the minimum detectable concentration of most fluorimeters. The presence of a single coordinated water molecule for the latter complex reduces the overall metal-centered luminescence.
elements.clean_text: The synthesis, characterization, and photophysical properties of two novel ligands, 5LINMe-1,2-HOPO (1) and H(2,2)-1,2-HOPO (2), which utilize the 1,2-HOPO chelate as a sensitizer for Eu(III) are reported. In addition, the former ligand was structurally characterized as the Eu(III) complex by X-ray crystallography. The [Eu(1)2]- complex of the tetradentate ligand (1) is stable in aqueous solution, to a limiting concentration of ca. 7 × 10-9 M, and retains the superior photophysical performance noted for the 1,2-HOPO sensitizer. By contrast, the octadentate ligand (2) has vastly improved stability as the [Eu(2)]- complex upon further dilution, to a limiting concentration of ca. 5 × 10-17 M, which is beyond the minimum detectable concentration of most fluorimeters. The presence of a single coordinated water molecule for the latter complex reduces the overall metal-centered luminescence.

elements.content: The synthesis, characterization, and photophysical properties of a tetradentate chelate, 5LINMe-1,2-HOPO, in complexes with Eu(III), are reported. This compound was designed as a model for H(2,2)-1,2-HOPO, (the ‘red-back spider', ‘Latrodectus Hasselti'), an octadentate ligand which delivers strong red emission in complex with Eu(III) upon ligand-centered excitation and demonstrates potent aqueous stability upon extremely high dilution to a theoretical limiting concentration of 5×10-17 M.
elements.clean_text: The synthesis, characterization, and photophysical properties of a tetradentate chelate, 5LINMe-1,2-HOPO, in complexes with Eu(III), are reported. This compound was designed as a model for H(2,2)-1,2-HOPO, (the ‘red-back spider', ‘Latrodectus Hasselti'), an octadentate ligand which delivers strong red emission in complex with Eu(III) upon ligand-centered excitation and demonstrates potent aqueous stability upon extremely high dilution to a theoretical limiting concentration of 5×10-17 M.

elements.content: Organic complexes of luminescent lanthanides such as Eu(III) have become increasingly useful for biological assays and in high-throughput screening applications, where their long-lived luminescence can allow significant improvement in the signal-to-noise ratio. Several Ln(III) chelates are commercially available (e.g., Lance, Perkin-Elmer; LanthaScreen, Invitrogen), and fluorescent assay platforms such as dissociation-enhanced lanthanide fluorescent immuno assay (DELFIA) are well developed, offering increased sensitivity compared to colorimetric assay formats such as enzyme-linked immuno sorbent assay (ELISA). Nonetheless, the quantum yield of these commercial luminescence agents are far from optimized (ca. 2−10%), and the improvement of this crucial parameter while maintaining sufficient aqueous solubility and stability for biological compatibility is a challenging area of active current interest.
elements.clean_text: Organic complexes of luminescent lanthanides such as Eu(III) have become increasingly useful for biological assays and in high-throughput screening applications, where their long-lived luminescence can allow significant improvement in the signal-to-noise ratio. Several Ln(III) chelates are commercially available (e.g., Lance, Perkin-Elmer; LanthaScreen, Invitrogen), and fluorescent assay platforms such as dissociation-enhanced lanthanide fluorescent immuno assay (DELFIA) are well developed, offering increased sensitivity compared to colorimetric assay formats such as enzyme-linked immuno sorbent assay (ELISA). Nonetheless, the quantum yield of these commercial luminescence agents are far from optimized (ca. 2-10%), and the improvement of this crucial parameter while maintaining sufficient aqueous solubility and stability for biological compatibility is a challenging area of active current interest.

elements.content: Structures of 5LIO-1,2-HOPO (3) (Top Left), 5LINMe-1,2-HOPO (1) (Bottom Left) and H(2,2)-1,2-HOPO (2) (Right)
elements.clean_text: 1  Structures of 5LIO-1,2-HOPO (3) (Top Left), 5LINMe-1,2-HOPO (1) (Bottom Left) and H(2,2)-1,2-HOPO (2) (Right)

elements.content: We recently reported6 the exceptional photophysical performance of tetradentate 1-hydroxypyridin-2-one derivatives such as 5LIO-1,2-HOPO (3) that form stable ML2 complexes with Eu(III). These ligands simultaneously fulfill the criteria of both high thermodynamic stability and excellent photophysical properties. Herein, we extend this family to include an amino-linked version 5LINMe-1,2-HOPO (1) (Chart ) which was developed as a model for H(2,2)-1,2-HOPO (2), the first example of an octadentate 1,2-HOPO derivative for Eu(III) luminescence. The latter forms an ML complex with improved stability upon dilution in aqueous solution, a feature required for the practical development and application of these complexes in biological assays.
elements.clean_text: We recently reported6 the exceptional photophysical performance of tetradentate 1-hydroxypyridin-2-one derivatives such as 5LIO-1,2-HOPO (3) that form stable ML2 complexes with Eu(III). These ligands simultaneously fulfill the criteria of both high thermodynamic stability and excellent photophysical properties. Herein, we extend this family to include an amino-linked version 5LINMe-1,2-HOPO (1) (Chart ) which was developed as a model for H(2,2)-1,2-HOPO (2), the first example of an octadentate 1,2-HOPO derivative for Eu(III) luminescence. The latter forms an ML complex with improved stability upon dilution in aqueous solution, a feature required for the practical development and application of these complexes in biological assays.

elements.content: The syntheses of 5LINMe-1,2-HOPO and H(2,2)-1,2-HOPO are straightforward (see Scheme S1, Supporting Information). Boc amidation of N-(2-aminoethyl)-ethane-1,2-diamine (dien) followed by reductive amination with formaldehyde provides the protected backbone which was converted to the 5LINMe amine by reaction with TFA. Alternately, the N,N,N‘,N‘-tetrakis-(2-aminoethyl)-ethane-1,2-diamine (H(2,2)) may be prepared using literature methods. Reaction of either backbone with the thiazaolide-activated 1,2-HOPO precursor yields the benzyl-protected ligands, which were deprotected under acidic conditions with 1:1 (v/v) AcOH/HCl (12 M). Complexation with EuCl3·6H2O in MeOH at reflux gave the desired complexes on cooling in good yield and analytically pure form. An X-ray-quality crystal of the [Eu(5LINMe-1,2-HOPO)2]- complex, as the potassium salt, was grown by slow evaporation of a ca. 500 μM solution in 0.1 M KCl at ca. pH 8.
elements.clean_text: The syntheses of 5LINMe-1,2-HOPO and H(2,2)-1,2-HOPO are straightforward (see Scheme S1, Supporting Information). Boc amidation of N-(2-aminoethyl)-ethane-1,2-diamine (dien) followed by reductive amination with formaldehyde provides the protected backbone which was converted to the 5LINMe amine by reaction with TFA. Alternately, the N,N,N‘,N‘-tetrakis-(2-aminoethyl)-ethane-1,2-diamine (H(2,2)) may be prepared using literature methods. Reaction of either backbone with the thiazaolide-activated 1,2-HOPO precursor yields the benzyl-protected ligands, which were deprotected under acidic conditions with 1:1 (v/v) AcOH/HCl (12 M). Complexation with EuCl3⋅6H2O in MeOH at reflux gave the desired complexes on cooling in good yield and analytically pure form. An X-ray-quality crystal of the [Eu(5LINMe-1,2-HOPO)2]- complex, as the potassium salt,  was grown by slow evaporation of a ca. 500 μM solution in 0.1 M KCl at ca. pH 8.

elements.content: As shown in Figure , the anionic Eu(III) complex of 1 forms an ML2 species, with an overall eight-coordinate central metal ion. Shape analysis, as discussed elsewhere, was used to assess the closest idealized coordination polyhedra, yielding the best fit to an approximate C 2 v geometry at the metal (see Table S1). Notably, the observed geometry is very similar to that previously reported6 for the structurally analogous ligand (3) with an ether linkage in the backbone. In the present case, as with the [Eu(3)2]- structure, the presence of four intramolecular hydrogen-bonding interactions is noted between the amide nitrogen protons and proximal phenolic oxygen atoms (av N−H···O = 1.97 Å). These interactions have been noted in several previous examples6,8 and impart additional stability to the ensuing metal complex. A potassium counter cation was also located at the base of each Eu(III) complex, which forms a trifurcated interaction with the O2, O6, and O7 oxygens of the anionic complex, and is bridged by amide carbonyl oxygens from three adjacent molecules (O3, O9, and O10) to form an extended coordination polymer network. The coordination sphere of the potassium ion is completed by a solvent water molecule, yielding an overall seven-coordinate cation (see Figure S1).
elements.clean_text: As shown in Figure , the anionic Eu(III) complex of 1 forms an ML2 species, with an overall eight-coordinate central metal ion. Shape analysis, as discussed elsewhere, was used to assess the closest idealized coordination polyhedra, yielding the best fit to an approximate C 2  v  geometry at the metal (see Table S1). Notably, the observed geometry is very similar to that previously reported6 for the structurally analogous ligand (3) with an ether linkage in the backbone. In the present case, as with the [Eu(3)2]- structure, the presence of four intramolecular hydrogen-bonding interactions is noted between the amide nitrogen protons and proximal phenolic oxygen atoms (av N-H⋅⋅⋅O = 1.97 Å). These interactions have been noted in several previous examples6,8 and impart additional stability to the ensuing metal complex. A potassium counter cation was also located at the base of each Eu(III) complex, which forms a trifurcated interaction with the O2, O6, and O7 oxygens of the anionic complex, and is bridged by amide carbonyl oxygens from three adjacent molecules (O3, O9, and O10) to form an extended coordination polymer network. The coordination sphere of the potassium ion is completed by a solvent water molecule, yielding an overall seven-coordinate cation (see Figure S1).

elements.content: X-ray structure of [Eu(5LINMe-1,2-HOPO)2]- (30% probability ellipsoids shown, Ortep 3). Solvent molecules, potassium counter cation, and selected H atoms have been omitted for clarity. Only one orientation of the disordered ligand backbone is shown.

elements.content:
Protonation and Eu(III) Complex Formation Constants of 5LINMe-1,2-HOPO Compared to Previously Reported6 5LIO-1,2-HOPO

5LINMe-1,2-HOPO 5LIO-1,2-HOPO pK1 3.76(3) 4.19(3) pK2 5.31(1) 5.79(1) pK3 8.13(1) N/A pEu7.4 17.3(1) 18.6(1) log β120 23.0(1) 22.9(1) log β121 30.5(5) 25.2(3) log β122 36.97(5) N/A log β123 41.5(1) N/A

Protonation and Eu(III) Complex Formation Constants of H(2,2)-1,2-HOPO

pK1 3.19(4) pEu8.5 21.7(1) pK2 4.27(3) pEu7.4 21.2(1) pK3 5.23(3) pEu6.1 20.0(1) pK4 6.22(2) log β110 21.8(5) pK5 7.77(1) log β111 31.2(3) pK6 10.43(2) log β112 38.1(2)

Ligand pKa's for 1 and 2 were determined by potentiometry, and resulting values are summarized in Tables and . For both ligands, the most basic protonation sites were assigned to the amine nitrogen atoms by comparison to previous reports. For the [Eu(1)2]- complex, a formation constant of log β120 = 23.0(1) was determined from the conditional stability constant (pEu7.4 = 17.3(1)), obtained by competition batch titration versus DTPA (see Figure S2). Subsequent potentiometric titrations could be refined with fixed ligand protonation constants and a fixed log β120 = 23.0, resulting in log β121 = 30.5(5), log β122 = 36.97(5), and log β123 = 41.5(1), with initial protonation sites of the metal complex most likely located at the basic amine functions, and a third (most acidic) protonation at one of the 1,2-HOPO chromophores. Preliminary stability data for the octadentate complex, [Eu(2)]-, were also determined via competition batch titration versus DTPA at pH 7.4, yielding a pEu of 21.2(1). Potentiometric titrations were hampered by a decrease in solubility of the complex below pH 7 (from >0.5 to ∼0.1 mM), which thwarted refinement of the titration data. Instead, additional competition batch titration versus DTPA at pH 6.1 and 8.5 were performed (see Figure S3). Values of log β110 = 21.8(5), log β111 = 31.2(3) and log β112 = 38.1(2) resulted from fits to these data, along with [Eu(2)]- complex protonation constants of pKa1 = 9.4(5) and pKa2 = 6.9(2) which, by analogy to [Eu(1)2]-, we assign to protonation of the amine backbone nitrogens. The complete solution thermodynamic model is described by the parameters summarized in Table . Assuming a tolerance of 1% free Eu(III), we calculate a theoretical stability limit for the [Eu(2)]- complex of ca. 5 × 10-17 M at pH 7.4 in the absence of competing species (Figure ), whereupon further dilution leads to hydrolysis of the complex. This limiting concentration is some 8 orders of magnitude improved when compared to the corresponding calculation for [Eu(1)2]-, which yields a limiting concentration of ca. 7 × 10-9 M (see Figure S4), demonstrating the dramatic enhancement of stability at high dilution due primarily to the entropic chelate effect when moving from a tetradentate to octadentate ligand topology.

For both ligands, the most basic protonation sites were assigned to the amine nitrogen atoms by comparison to previous reports. For the [Eu(1)2]- complex, a formation constant of log β120 = 23.0(1) was determined from the conditional stability constant (pEu7.4 = 17.3(1)), obtained by competition batch titration versus DTPA (see Figure S2). Subsequent potentiometric titrations could be refined with fixed ligand protonation constants and a fixed log β120 = 23.0, resulting in log β121 = 30.5(5), log β122 = 36.97(5), and log β123 = 41.5(1), with initial protonation sites of the metal complex most likely located at the basic amine functions, and a third (most acidic) protonation at one of the 1,2-HOPO chromophores. Preliminary stability data for the octadentate complex, [Eu(2)]-, were also determined via competition batch titration versus DTPA at pH 7.4, yielding a pEu of 21.2(1). Potentiometric titrations were hampered by a decrease in solubility of the complex below pH 7 (from >0.5 to ~0.1 mM), which thwarted refinement of the titration data. Instead, additional competition batch titration versus DTPA at pH 6.1 and 8.5 were performed (see Figure S3).  Values of log β110 = 21.8(5), log β111 = 31.2(3) and log β112 = 38.1(2) resulted from fits to these data, along with [Eu(2)]- complex protonation constants of pKa1 = 9.4(5) and pKa2 = 6.9(2) which, by analogy to [Eu(1)2]-, we assign to protonation of the amine backbone nitrogens. The complete solution thermodynamic model is described by the parameters summarized in Table . Assuming a tolerance of 1% free Eu(III), we calculate a theoretical stability limit for the [Eu(2)]- complex of ca. 5 × 10-17 M at pH 7.4 in the absence of competing species (Figure ), whereupon further dilution leads to hydrolysis of the complex. This limiting concentration is some 8 orders of magnitude improved when compared to the corresponding calculation for [Eu(1)2]-, which yields a limiting concentration of ca. 7 × 10-9 M (see Figure S4), demonstrating the dramatic enhancement of stability at high dilution due primarily to the entropic chelate effect when moving from a tetradentate to octadentate ligand topology.

elements.content: The electronic absorption spectra for the [Eu(2)]- and [Eu(1)2]- complexes are shown in Figure and S5, respectively, and are typical of that observed for the 1,2-HOPO chromophore, comprising an n−π* transition at ca. 330−340 nm and more intense π−π* bands to higher energy. Notably, the spectrum of [Eu(2)]- has a slightly red-shifted λmax at 341 nm, ca. 800 cm-1 lower than the [Eu(1)2]- complex. The luminescence spectrum of [Eu(2)]- is also shown in Figure , and is typical of that for the Eu(III) cation in a low-symmetry environment (vide infra).
elements.clean_text: The electronic absorption spectra for the [Eu(2)]- and [Eu(1)2]- complexes are shown in Figure  and S5, respectively, and are typical of that observed for the 1,2-HOPO chromophore, comprising an n-π* transition at ca. 330-340 nm and more intense π-π* bands to higher energy. Notably, the spectrum of [Eu(2)]- has a slightly red-shifted λmax at 341 nm, ca. 800 cm-1 lower than the [Eu(1)2]- complex. The luminescence spectrum of [Eu(2)]- is also shown in Figure , and is typical of that for the Eu(III) cation in a low-symmetry environment (vide infra).

elements.content: A summary of the relevant photophysical parameters determined experimentally (and calculated from the emission spectrum as discussed elsewhere11) for [Eu(1)2]- and [Eu(2)]- is given in Table . Most notably, the quantum yield determined (see Supporting Information) for [Eu(1)2]- is comparable to that previously reported6 for the analogous [Eu(3)2]- complex, while the corresponding value of Φtot = 3.6% ± 0.5% for [Eu(2)]- is almost an order of magnitude less than the tetradentate model compounds.
elements.clean_text: A summary of the relevant photophysical parameters determined experimentally (and calculated from the emission spectrum as discussed elsewhere11) for [Eu(1)2]- and [Eu(2)]- is given in Table . Most notably, the quantum yield determined (see Supporting Information) for [Eu(1)2]- is comparable to that previously reported6 for the analogous [Eu(3)2]- complex, while the corresponding value of Φtot = 3.6% ± 0.5% for [Eu(2)]- is almost an order of magnitude less than the tetradentate model compounds.

elements.content:
Summary of Experimental and Calculated Photophysical Parameters for [Eu(5LINMe-1,2-HOPO)2]- and [Eu(H(2,2)-1,2-HOPO)]- Complexes

complex λmax, εmax (nm, M-1 cm-1) Φtot (H2O) τobs H2O, {D2O} (μs) k r, calcd (ms-1) k nr, calcd (ms-1) ΦEu, calcd ηsens, calcd [Eu(5LINMe−1,2-HOPO)2] 332, 18 750 0.173 ± 0.026 728 ± 2.8 {1000 ± 2.5} 0.61 0.77 0.442 0.391 [Eu(H(2,2)-1,2-HOPO)] 341, 18 200 0.036 ± 0.005 480 ± 1.2 {1222 ± 2.5} 0.38 1.75 0.178 0.202

The corresponding luminescence lifetimes were evaluated for both complexes in aqueous and deuterated solvent, allowing the degree of hydration, q, to be estimated using the recently improved Horrocks equation. The resulting q values for [Eu(1)2]- and [Eu(2)]- were 0.07 and 1.06 ± 0.1 respectively. Accordingly, while [Eu(1)2]- receives an effective degree of protection from nonradiative deactivation by solvent interactions, it appears that the [Eu(2)]- complex retains a single bound water molecule in the metal's first coordination sphere. Since the non-radiative decay rate of the Eu(III) cation is known12 to be strongly influenced by the presence of proximal OH oscillators, this explains the poor photophysical performance for [Eu(2)(H2O)]-. Furthermore, it appears both the radiative decay rate, k r, and the energy transfer efficiency (from ligand to metal), ηsens, are lower for [Eu(2)(H2O)]- for reasons which are not yet readily apparent and are currently being investigated.
elements.clean_text: The corresponding luminescence lifetimes were evaluated for both complexes in aqueous and deuterated solvent, allowing the degree of hydration, q, to be estimated using the recently improved Horrocks equation. The resulting q values for [Eu(1)2]- and [Eu(2)]- were 0.07 and 1.06 ± 0.1 respectively. Accordingly, while [Eu(1)2]- receives an effective degree of protection from nonradiative deactivation by solvent interactions, it appears that the [Eu(2)]- complex retains a single bound water molecule in the metal's first coordination sphere. Since the non-radiative decay rate of the Eu(III) cation is known12 to be strongly influenced by the presence of proximal OH oscillators, this explains the poor photophysical performance for [Eu(2)(H2O)]-. Furthermore, it appears both the radiative decay rate, k r, and the energy transfer efficiency (from ligand to metal), ηsens, are lower for [Eu(2)(H2O)]- for reasons which are not yet readily apparent and are currently being investigated.

elements.content: Last, it has been shown that the observed emission spectra can be used to yield an insight into the solution structure of Eu(III) complexes. The corresponding q measurements determined a nine-coordinate coordination polyhedron for [Eu(2)(H2O)]-. However, a consideration of the symmetry-allowed transitions (see Table S3) did not yield a satisfactory match to either the tricapped trigonal prismatic (D 3 h ) or monocapped square antiprismatic (C 4 v ) geometries. Rather, a closer analysis of the J = 1 band reveals a splitting of the degenerate E state of the latter into two 2B bands (see Figure S6), consistent with a local C 2 site symmetry for the metal ion. This can be rationalized by the C 2 geometry enforced by the ligand. An optimized MM3 model of the [Eu(2)(H2O)]- complex is shown in Figure and supports this assignment.
elements.clean_text: Last, it has been shown that the observed emission spectra can be used to yield an insight into the solution structure of Eu(III) complexes. The corresponding q measurements determined a nine-coordinate coordination polyhedron for [Eu(2)(H2O)]-. However, a consideration of the symmetry-allowed transitions (see Table S3) did not yield a satisfactory match to either the tricapped trigonal prismatic (D 3  h ) or monocapped square antiprismatic (C 4  v ) geometries. Rather, a closer analysis of the J = 1 band reveals a splitting of the degenerate E state of the latter into two 2B bands (see Figure S6), consistent with a local C 2 site symmetry for the metal ion. This can be rationalized by the C 2 geometry enforced by the ligand. An optimized MM3 model of the [Eu(2)(H2O)]- complex is shown in Figure  and supports this assignment.

elements.content:
Our efforts are now turning toward eliminating the residual water molecule in order to improve the luminescent characteristics of these octadentate 1,2-HOPO derivatives.

<ext-link xlink:href="/doi/suppl/10.1021%2Fic700364t">Supporting Information Available</ext-link>

Synthesis of 5LINMe-1,2-HOPO, H(2,2)-1,2-HOPO, and Eu(III) complexes. Shape analysis results and crystal data (cif) for [K(H2O)Eu(1)2]·H2O. Details of solution thermodynamic experiments and photophysical data. This material is available free of charge via the Internet at http:// pubs.acs.org.
